Award.AwardTitle: 2015 International Workshop on Robotics and Interactive Technologies For Neuroscience and Rehabilitation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1542301
Mussa-Ivaldi, Ferdinando A.

Since its inception, Robotics has had a profound impact on our understanding of how the brain constructs movements, processes sensory information and adapts to variable environments. In more recent times it has entered the clinical domain of sensory-motor rehabilitation for survivors of stroke and other disabling neurological conditions.

The proposed workshop is intended to organize a vigorous debate between experts in robotics, in rehabilitation research and in the basic neuroscience of the sensory-motor system with the dual purpose of enhancing the integration of these disciplines and developing new international collaborations between centers of excellence for Neurotechnologies and Rehabilitation in the United States and Italy.
Therefore, the general goal of the workshop will be to promote the progress of science in the critical area where robotics and neuroscience are going to meet and interact, with a specific emphasis on state of the art advances in the national health, in relation with the increasing percentage of senior citizens in all industrialized countries of the world. Moreover, the project will advance the rehabilitation field strengthening the leadership of US research.

The debate on the hot issues of Advanced Robotics and Robotic Neurorehabilitation will be organized by scientists from two institutions, namely the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago (RIC) - the leading US hospital for rehabilitation research - and the Italian Institute of Technology (IIT) - the leading Italian research center for a broad spectrum of advanced technologies, including neurorehabilitation, robotics and nanotechnology. The interaction between these two research centers is intended to be a seed for developing a broader collaborative network of US and Italian researchers in neurorehabilitation science and technology. The significance of this initiative stems from its potential to enhance and maintain the close contiguity of insights from basic neuroscience with the ingenuity of rapid technological developments in the clinical domain. It is expected that this tight interaction will serve to promote the recovery of lost abilities and independence in the disabled population, while expanding the intellectual and educational domains for current and future generations of researchers in neural engineering.

The three-days workshop will include four discussion sessions, on the following themes:

1. Sensory-motor control and haptic interactions.
2. Learning and motor cognition.
3. Human/machine interactions.
4. Neuroprosthetics and rehabilitation

Each theme will be introduced by brief presentations from IIT and RIC experts, followed by more detailed demonstrations and descriptions of key scientific and technological issues. A group of panelists will guide the discussion, inclusive of all participants, during and at the end of the meeting, by pointing at specific unresolved problems and future challenges. Participation of junior scientists will be particularly encouraged both during the meeting and through the preparation of articles that will be collected in the submission for a special issue of Frontiers Research Topics. On the third day, principal investigators from both institutions will visit the IIT laboratories. There, a discussion of the perspective collaborations that have emerged in the previous two days will conclude the workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award has enabled an international workshop on "Robotic and Interactive Technologies for Neuroscience and Neurorehabilitation" to take  place in Arenzano (Italy) between August 31 and September 2, 2015 (Figure 1). The workshop has promoted the exchange research perspectives  and has established the basis for future collaborations between researchers in the USA and Italy from two top research institutions in these countries: the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago (RIC) and the Italian Institute of Technologies, with headquarters in Genoa.

Eighty-eight  people attended the meeting. A complete list of registered attendants with a brief description of their research interests  can be found at

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1i68JPc7lrS46c-VLT5DAmLVIL19L8dq9HLLp9yDLATg/edit#slide=id.g6473bda76_2_117

The meeting was organized sequentially into 5 themes. These were:

1) Sensory Motor Control

2) Learning and Motor Cognition

3) Neural Interfaces and Haptics Technology

4) Neuroprosthetics and Rehabilitation

5) Bio-Inspired Robotic

Each theme was divided into two parts: a) Framework talks were intended to provide a broad overview of key issues, and b) Research talks were focused on key specific state-of-the-art accomplishments.

Collateral to the oral session, the Workshop included two poster sessions.  A total of 60 presentations were collected in a Book of Abstracts that was distributed to the participants. 

Two keynote talks were included in the program, by Prof. Emilio Bizzi (MIT) and by Prof. Paolo Bonato. The keynote offered a broad perspective on the interactions between basic Neuroscience approaches to the study of the sensory-motor system and  the development of therapeutic and assistive technologies for people suffering from a variety of  neurological disorders and accidents. At the end of the second day of the workshop the participants divided into discussion groups to discuss the main challenges offered by the 5 themes. Each group had 4 discussion leaders selected from the RIC and the IIT senior participants.

The IEEE Transactions on neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering (TNSRE) is currently in the process of publishing a special issue  that collects 10 key contributions from workshop participants.  The following articles are in the special issue:

 

Avila Mireles EJ, Zenzeri J, Squeri V, Morasso P, and Dalia De Santis. Skill learning and skill transfer mediated by cooperative haptic interaction.

Peternel L, Tsagarakis N, and Arash Ajoudani. A Human-Robot Co-Manipulation Approach Based on Human Sensorimotor Information.

Loram ID, Bate B, Harding P, Cunningham R, and Alison Loram. Proactive selective inhibition targeted at the neck muscles: this proximal constraint facilitates learning and regulates global control.

Semprini M, Cuppone AV, Delis I, Squeri V, Stefano Panzeri S, and Jürgen Konczak. Biofeedback Signals for Robotic Rehabilitation: Assessment of Wrist Muscle Activation Patterns in Healthy Humans.

Bartoli E, Caso F, Magnani G, and Gabriel Baud-Bovy. Low-cost robotic assessment of visuo-motor deficits in Alzheimer’s disease.

Mooney LM and Elliott J. Rouse.  Design and Characterization of a Quasi-Passive Pneumatic Foot-Ankle Prothesis.

Leo L, Cocchi E, and Luca Brayda. The effect of programmable tactile maps on spatial learning skills in children and adolescents of different visual disability.

Zhang LQ,  Son J, Park HS, Ren Y, Sang Kang SH, and Yunju Lee. Changes of Shoulder, Elbow and Wrist Stiffness Matrix Post Stroke.

Laczko J, Scheidt RA, Simo LS, Piovesan D. Inter-joint coordination deficits revealed in the decomposition of endpoint jerk during goal-directed arm movement after stroke.

De Luca A, Giannoni P, Vernetti H, Capra C, Lentino C, Checchia GA, Casadio M. Training the unimpaired arm improves the motion of the impaired arm and the sitting balance in chronic stroke survivors.
